newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin names ex-journalist his chief of staff.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin names ex-journalist his chief of staff.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin on Tuesday named an ex-journalist with no bureaucratic background as his chief of staff in a move to end a tug-of-war between the Kremlin administration and the Russian government.
Valentin Yumashev, 39, replaces Anatoly Chubais, 41, who has been transferred to the government as first deputy prime minister to improve its performance and revitalise economic reform.

Before the summer of 1996, when the newly re-elected Yeltsin formally named Yumashev as an aide, the journalist had made his name in the liberal press and ghost-wrote at least one of the president's books, his 1991 autobiography "Against the Grain".

Yumashev, who formerly held the post of editor-in-chief at the respected liberal weekly magazine Ogonyok, told Interfax news agency on Tuesday that he did not plan any changes in the presidential administration.

But political analysts have predicted that Chubais' departure will certainly change many things in the functions of the presidential administration, which many opponents have described as a "parallel government".

Under Yeltsin's plans for a cabinet reshuffle Chubais, who kick-started privatisation in Russia and has gained in influence during Yeltsin's absences through illness in the past eight months, will be the only first deputy premier.
He and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin have worked hand in hand to keep Russia under control and stable in the absence of Yeltsin.
Until now Chubais and Chernomyrdin have vigilantly preserved the power balance between government and presidential administration as a basis for national political stability.

Yeltsin, who is now back in the Kremlin and appears to have recovered his health and determination to play a strong and independent role in Russian politics, broke this balance last week by moving Chubais to the government.
Interfax quoted Yeltsin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky as saying the departure of Chubais would not weaken the Kremlin administration.
"There are no resons to cut in any way the powers of the presidential administration," he said. "They are defined (by law)."

But some political commentators suggested that, by appointing a much less powerful political figure as his new chief of staff, Yeltsin could be changing his administration from a powerbase to a personal chancellery.
